title: Adidas tumbles in Europe as supply chain woes and a tough China market hit results
text:
A top decliner, Adidas XE:ADS fell 5% after saying it now expects full-year top and bottom lines to be at the lower end of guidance. The sportswear maker reported a 600 million euros ($696 million) hit to quarterly revenue due to a challenging China market, COVID-related lockdowns across Asia and supply-chain disruptions.

Management had guided for those woes in August. Shares have underperformed Nike NKE, Puma XE:PUM and the global sporting goods sector, year to date, but “are unlikely to recover near-term, we think, until current supply chain and Covid-related disruption diminish.,” Citi analyst Thomas Chauvet told clients in a note.

Still, he said these are “temporary factors” and unlikely to compromise the company's ambitious “Own the Game” 2025 growth targets introduced in March, and Chauvet is sticking to a buy rating.

Shares of Adidas rival Puma fell 1.7%

The Stoxx Europe 600 index XX:SXXP slipped 0.2% to 482.12. Of the major regional indexes, the German DAX DX:DAX was flat, the French CAC 40 FR:PX1 declined 0.3% and the U.K. FTSE 100 UK:UKX increased 0.5%.

The softer action for stocks came with Wall Street headed for a weaker day of trading as October consumer prices came in higher than expected on several measures. It comes on the heel of a surge in China producer prices to the highest level since 1996 reported on Wednesday. Consumer prices also rose in the country.

In Europe, German consumer prices rose 4.5% on the year, which were in line with the forecasts of economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.

The biggest Stoxx 600 gainer Marks & Spencer UK:MKS , up 15% after the U.K. retailer swung to a pretax first-half profit and lifted guidance. Just behind it was ITV UK:ITV, which rose 14%, The U.K. broadcaster said it expects advertising revenue to rise on the year in its crucial fourth quarter, and has struck a long-term commercial partnership deal with Virgin Media.

Another big gainer was Swedish retail chain ICA Gruppen SE:ICA, with those shares up AB said Wednesday it has received a takeover offer that values the company at 107.4 billion Swedish kronor ($12.5 billion).

Siemens Energy XE:ENR shares rose 2.4% after the German energy company reported narrower losses in its fiscal fourth quarter on higher revenue and issued guidance for fiscal 2022. Shares of rival E.ON XE:EOAN rose 1% after reporting higher profit and sales in the third quarter, and backing its forecasts for the year.

The biggest Stoxx 600 faller was S4 Capital UK:SFOR, which fell 10% after the digital advertising and marketing-services company reported in-line revenue growth as strong momentum continued in the third quarter.

Infineon Technologies XE:IFX posted higher profit and revenue in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2021 as it continued to benefit from high demand for semiconductors, and said it expects a strong fiscal 2022. But the German chipmaker's shares slipped 1%.
